title: 106_hr764
content:
The "Child Abuse Prevention and Enforcement Act" includes provisions for enhancing the criminal justice system's ability to provide criminal history information to child welfare agencies. Additionally, funds from the Byrne Grant Program can be used for child protection purposes. SEC. 103 amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act to include enforcing child abuse laws and supporting programs to prevent child abuse. It also allows for cooperative programs between law enforcement and media organizations. SEC. 104 addresses a conditional adjustment in the set-aside for child abuse victims under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. Section 1402(d)(2) of the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to allocate funds for grants under section 1404A based on the increase in the amount deposited in the Fund from fiscal year 1998, not exceeding $20,000,000. The increase in funding provided shall operate notwithstanding any dollar limitation on the availability of the Crime Victims Fund established under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. TITLE II--JENNIFER'S LAW

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as ``Jennifer's Law''.

SEC. 202. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED.

The Attorney General can grant awards to States to improve reporting of unidentified and missing persons.

SEC. 203. ELIGIBILITY. To be eligible for a grant award under this title, a State must submit an application with assurances to report deceased unidentified persons to law enforcement authorities and enter their profiles in the National Crime Information Center Missing and Unidentified Persons File as per Department of Justice guidelines. To be eligible for a grant award, a State must report deceased unidentified persons to law enforcement and enter their profiles in the National Crime Information Center until identification. A State receiving a grant under this title can use the funds to improve reporting of unidentified persons. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2000-2002.
